DataElement.preferredName: Slide Specimen Assessment Nucleus Abnormality Extent Category
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term that describes the extent of nuclear atypia and/or anaplasia.

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study._A part of a thing, or of several things, taken to demonstrate or to determine the character of the whole, e.g. a substance, or portion of material obtained for use in testing, examination, or study; particularly, a preparation of tissue or bodily fluid taken for examination or diagnosis._Having determined the value, significance, or extent of.

Concepts.definition: A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.

A part of a thing, or of several things, taken to demonstrate or to determine the character of the whole, e.g. a substance, or portion of material obtained for use in testing, examination, or study; particularly, a preparation of tissue or bodily fluid taken for examination or diagnosis.

Property.preferredDefinition: Having determined the value, significance, or extent of.

Concepts.definition: The final result of a determination of the value, significance, or extent of.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

DataElementConcept.changeDescription: Curated for The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) by request of L.Dillon 4/2011

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Within a eukaryotic cell, a membrane-limited body which contains chromosomes and one or more nucleoli (CELL NUCLEOLUS). The nuclear membrane consists of a double unit-type membrane which is perforated by a number of pores; the outermost membrane is continuous with the ENDOPLASMIC RETICULUM. A cell may contain more than one nucleus. (From Singleton & Sainsbury, Dictionary of Microbiology and Molecular Biology, 2d ed)_A condition that differs from the usual physical or mental state._The range, magnitude, or distance over which a thing spans an interval of distance, space, or time._Category; used informally to mean a class of things.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: High; greater than normal in degree or intensity or amount.

Concepts.definition: An elevated level or position or degree; greater than normal in degree or intensity or amount.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The quality of being within reasonable or average limits; not excessive or extreme.

Concepts.definition: The quality of being within reasonable or average limits; not excessive or extreme.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A minimum level or position or degree; less than normal in degree or intensity or amount.

Concepts.definition: A minimum level or position or degree; less than normal in degree, intensity or amount.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Within a eukaryotic cell, a membrane-limited body which contains chromosomes and one or more nucleoli (CELL NUCLEOLUS). The nuclear membrane consists of a double unit-type membrane which is perforated by a number of pores; the outermost membrane is continuous with the ENDOPLASMIC RETICULUM. A cell may contain more than one nucleus. (From Singleton & Sainsbury, Dictionary of Microbiology and Molecular Biology, 2d ed):A condition that differs from the usual physical or mental state.:The range, magnitude, or distance over which a thing spans an interval of distance, space, or time.:Category; used informally to mean a class of things.

Concepts.definition: A body within the cell, surrounded by a membrane, within which lie the chromosomes, one or more nucleoli, combined with proteins, and exhibits mitosis.
A condition that differs from the usual physical or mental state.
The range, magnitude, or distance over which a thing spans an interval of distance, space, or time.
A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.

ValueDomain.changeDescription: Curated for The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) by request of L.Dillon 4/2011
